intro_intake.text:
You do not wake at the Ninth Gate.
You become aware of it.

Cold stone presses against your back or shoulder—never painfully, just enough that you register you have been still for some time.

The air carries damp limestone, old ash, and a faint metallic tang that could be iron—or could be something else you don’t want to name yet.

Memory returns in assembled pieces.

A line that did not move forward so much as compress.
Voices kept low.
No shouting.
No threats.

When you asked questions, the answers were careful and procedural, as if no one present was allowed to improvise.

You were asked your name.
Something else was written down instead.

After that, time stopped behaving normally.
Doors opened that did not look guarded.
Corridors stretched longer than they should have.

Now—

the bars are in front of you.
The corridor is beyond them.
And your breath sounds too loud in the quiet.

intro_cellblock.text:
The cell is narrow, but not cruelly so.
Wide enough to lie down.
Narrow enough that pacing would feel like a performance for no one.

Iron bars face a corridor lit by a single torch mounted high on the wall.
The flame burns clean and steady.
It throws light across the floor and bars, but leaves the corners dim.

You could see someone coming long before they reached you.

Across the corridor, other cells line the wall.
One is empty, straw undisturbed.
Another holds a man sitting upright against the stone, knees drawn close, eyes closed.
He has not moved since you became aware of him.

Footsteps pass from time to time.
Not patrols.
Just movement.
People going somewhere.

A shallow bowl rests near the bars.
Thin broth.
Warm.
Enough to keep you alive.
Not enough to enjoy.

Sleep comes, but it never goes deep.
Your eyes close at some point—you’re certain of that.
But your mind never fully releases its grip on the space.

When awareness returns, it feels less like waking and more like continuing.

Then the corridor changes.

Not in what it is—
in how it feels.

Attended.

Footsteps stop near your cell.
A guard stands just beyond the bars.

Plain armor.
King Canaan’s colors, worn but intact.

He checks the torch first, adjusts it slightly, then looks at you.

"You’re awake," he says.
It isn’t a question.

"You’ll be moved later. No schedule."

He pauses, then adds, as if remembering something minor:

"If you need water before then, speak now."

intro_agency_water.text:
The guard does not rush you.
He does not pressure you.

The moment feels ordinary—and somehow important.

PLAYER AGENCY BEGINS HERE.

Do you ask for water?

choices.label: Ask who decides when you’re moved.

intro_agency_water.speaker: guard
intro_agency_water.dialogue: If you need water before then, speak now.

r_water_yes.text:
The guard nods once.

He does not smile.
He does not soften.

He simply turns his head slightly.

Another figure steps into the torchlight as if they had been standing there the whole time.
A cup is slid through the bars.

The water is cool.
Clean.
Almost insulting.

You drink.

The guard watches—not your thirst, but your manner.
How quickly.
How much.
Whether your hands shake.

When you’re done, the cup is retrieved with the same quiet precision.

The guard speaks again, as if stating weather:
The bell may sound.
Stand when it does.

r_water_silent.text:
You say nothing.

The guard waits long enough that your silence becomes a choice instead of an omission.

Then he nods—as if he has received the answer he expected.

No schedule, he repeats.
And no explanations.

He steps away.

The corridor resumes moving.
Somewhere farther down the hall, a door opens and closes with the weight of a mechanism doing what it was built to do.

r_water_question.text:
You ask who decides.

The guard’s expression does not change, but his posture tightens—subtle, trained.

He looks past you for half a second, toward the corridor behind.

Assessment decides, he says.

Not a name.
Not a person.
A function.

Then, as if the exchange has been filed and closed:

If you need water before movement, speak now.

r_water_watch.text:
You don’t answer.

You watch the seams in his armor.
The wear marks at the elbow.
The way his hand rests near a ring of keys he never touches.

He notices the watching.

Not offended.
Not threatened.

Recorded.

He checks the torch again—unnecessarily—then steps away.

The corridor returns to its quiet rhythm.
Your cell does not feel smaller.
It feels more observed.

arc1_intake_1.text:
A bell sounds once.

Not loud.
Not urgent.

Just present.

Locks answer it.
Doors open along the corridor one after another, each release timed as if the Gate prefers symmetry.

A guard does not enter your cell.
He stands aside and gestures.

The corridor air is cooler than the cell.
It smells faintly of wet stone and boiled grain.

You step out and find yourself inside a line that forms without instruction.

No one speaks.

At the far end, a man sits at a narrow desk, writing.

Beside him stands a woman with hands folded behind her back. She watches each person approach.

When you stand before the desk, the man continues writing for a moment longer before pausing.

He asks for your name.

The woman’s eyes do not leave your face.

arc1_corridor_1.text:
The man writes something.

The scratch of his pen is the loudest sound in the room.

The woman’s gaze does not move.

You are not sure which is worse—
the writing, or the watching.

A guard gestures.

You are guided past a wall lined with narrow plaques. Each bears a number.

None bear names.

The corridor bends.
Torchlight follows the bend as if it has learned the shape of the place.

You pass through another door.

choices.label: Focus on the faint draft ahead.

arc1_mark_1.text:
The draft touches your face as you pass the plaques.

Not strong enough to promise an exit.
Just strong enough to suggest there is space beyond the stone.

A latch clicks.

The door behind you closes.
The door ahead opens.

You are not shoved.
You are not restrained.

You are routed.

And the Gate does it without drama.

arc1_cell_1.text:
The door closes.

The space is small but clean.

A stone platform rests against one wall.
A shallow basin sits in the corner.

The slit of light shifts slowly across the opposite wall.

You hear distant movement through stone.

Not screams.
Not pleas.

Procedure.

Even the silence feels maintained.

choices.label: Listen for patterns in the sounds.

arc1_bell_1.text:
Time passes without announcing itself.

Then:

A bell.

Doors open along the corridor.

You are directed into line.

No words are exchanged.

As you walk, someone ahead falters briefly before steadying themselves.

No one reacts.

The line continues.
That, too, is a kind of message.

choices.label: Try to look into other cells.

arc1_eye_1.text:
The brush scrapes softly.

Stone dust gathers beneath your fingers.

Somewhere behind you, another brush keeps time.

While working, you feel someone watching.

Across the corridor, a man meets your gaze briefly.

He looks away first.

Later, you notice a woman moving her brush in a deliberate rhythm—three strokes, pause, three strokes.

No one speaks.

But the corridor is full of communication anyway.

choices.label: Maintain eye contact with the man.

arc1_return_1.text:
A bell sounds.

Not closer.
Not farther.

Just present.

Brushes are collected without ceremony.

Hands rise.
Handles are taken.

No one lingers.

You are returned to your cell.

The light now strikes the opposite wall.

The air feels heavier.

As if the Gate has tightened a fraction around the day you just lived.

choices.label: Replay the day in your mind.

arc1_night_1.text:
Darkness arrives gradually.

No torches.
No patrol calls.

Only the sound of distant doors closing one by one.

You become aware of your breathing.

It feels louder than it should.

Then you realize the more unsettling truth:

It is not louder.

Everything else has become quieter.

As if the Gate is listening.

choices.label: Listen for movement beyond the wall.

arc1_morning_gate.text:
The bell.

Your body rises before your mind finishes deciding.

The corridor you enter is not the same one from yesterday.

It is narrower.

The air is cooler.

Something has shifted.

You understand the rhythm now.

You also understand this:

Nothing here explains itself.

The Gate does not argue.

It simply routes.

arc1_falsevector_hint.text:
Your fingers find a seam.

Stone that should be uniform gives slightly differently under pressure.

For a moment, you feel air where there should be none.

The corridor remains silent.

Then—footsteps.

Not hurried.

Simply present.

Whatever you touched, the Gate felt it.

Or something inside the Gate did.

choices.label: Let go immediately and resume brushing.

arc1_absorption_event.text:
Stone shifts more than it should.

A thin panel yields.

For a moment—

You see not outside.

Only more corridor.

More stone.

More plaques.

A bell sounds.

Not the usual bell.

Lower.

The panel resets.

Footsteps approach.

A guard stands beside you.

He does not speak.

He gestures.

You are escorted back.

Not punished.

Repositioned.

The next morning, the plaques are different.

And you cannot prove to yourself that they weren’t always different.

arc1_night_after_absorb.text:
Your cell is not the same.

It is the same size.

The same stone.

The same light slit.

And yet it is not the same.

The bell cycle continues.

The Gate does not argue.

It simply repositions.

You lie down and realize your body has learned something without telling you:

Where the wall is.
Where the floor is.
Where the air feels wrong.

choices.label: Breathe. Count the bell cycle in your head.
Press your ear to the wall and listen.

arc1_near_miss.text:
The line forms.

A guard stands with a tablet.

He begins reading names.

One.

Another.

Then he pauses.

His finger stops on the page.

Your breathing slows without permission.

He looks up.

Not at you.

He reads another name.

The line moves.

The moment passes.

You are still here.

No one tells you what you almost were.

arc1_reassigned_official.text:
The line forms.

A guard stands with a tablet.

He reads names.

One.

Another.

Then he pauses.

Your name.

No tone change.

No explanation.

You step out of line.

The corridor you enter slopes downward slightly.

The air changes.

Not freer.

Different.

You are being moved.

Not released.

Reassigned.

arc1_hidden_door_prompt.text:
The corridor narrows.

A faint draft touches your face.

A door that was sealed yesterday sits slightly ajar.

No one reacts.

No one looks.

The line continues.

The opening remains.

Small.

Patient.

Real.

And the most dangerous thing about it is this:

It does not feel like a trap.

It feels like an option the system pretends not to see.

arc1_death_absorbed.text:
The bell sounds.

You do not rise.

The door opens.

A guard stands and waits.

You cannot stand.

There is no shouting.

No anger.

Only procedure.

You are lifted.

The corridor passes.

Plaques.

Stone.

Then less sound.

Then none.

The Gate continues.

Without you.

arc2_placeholder.text:
The corridor continues downward.

The air grows cooler.

Voices exist here—but not for you.

Not yet.

(Arc 2 is not deployed in this build.)

arc2_placeholder_lateral.text:
You move sideways.

Not out.

Deeper.

Stone shifts behind you.

The line never stops.

No alarm sounds.

The Gate does not announce mistakes.

It only routes them.

(Arc 2 is not deployed in this build.)

work_brush_1.text:
You are led into a work corridor.

Not a workshop.
Not a yard.

A corridor.

As if even labor must remain inside the spine of the place.

A guard sets a brush into your hands.
The handle is worn smooth by many palms.

The lower portion of the wall shows faint residue.
Something that has been scrubbed many times.

Others kneel and begin brushing in silence.

No one supervises directly.

And yet you can feel it:

Being watched.

Not personally.

Systemically.

choices.label: Test the stone instead of brushing.

r_brush_begin.text:
You take the brush.

The bristles are stiff with old grit.

You lower your arm and begin.

Stone gives nothing back, only dust.

Across the corridor, a guard’s posture shifts—an acknowledgement so small it could be imagined.

r_brush_observe.text:
You wait half a breath.

Not long enough to be defiance.

Long enough to learn.

You watch wrists, pressure, rhythm.

You notice who rushes and who pretends not to.

Then you begin.

r_brush_thorough.text:
You work as if the stone is watching.

Long strokes. Even pressure.

The brush squeals once—too loud.

A worker beside you flinches.

No one speaks.

You slow, then continue, controlled.

work_water_1.text:
You are handed a sloshing bucket.

Warm water. Not clean. Not foul.

A line of you moves down a narrow corridor where stone channels drink whatever spills.

The task is simple:
carry.

The difficulty is that nothing here is only a task.

choices.label: Match the pace of the person ahead.
Watch the guard’s hands, not his face.

r_water_carry_steady.text:
Your arms burn slowly.

You keep the surface level.

The water trembles, but does not spill.

A guard passes you without looking.

Somehow, that feels like approval.

r_water_carry_fast.text:
You speed up.

The bucket answers immediately.

Water slaps the rim and runs down your wrist.

The corridor’s channel drinks it.

A guard’s gaze touches you—brief, cold, recorded.

You slow down without being told.

r_water_carry_match.text:
You adjust to the body in front of you.

Not friendship.

Not alliance.

Just synchronization.

For a moment the line moves like one thing.

The Gate likes that.

r_water_carry_watch.text:
You watch his hands.

They are clean.

No tremor.

No impatience.

The ring on his finger is plain, worn at the edges.

He notices you noticing.

His hands do not change.

Your grip tightens anyway.

work_linen_1.text:
A stack of linen is dropped on a table.

Not bedding.
Not clothing.

Strips.
Folded and refolded.

Each bundle has a wax tag stamped with a number.

The task is sorting.

The test is whether you treat the numbers like they matter.

choices.label: Sort by cleanliness instead of numbers.
Swap two tags when no one is looking.

r_linen_sort_exact.text:
You place each bundle where it belongs.

The numbers become a rhythm.

Order without meaning.

A clerk passes and makes a small mark on a slate.

Not praise.

Just recording.

r_linen_sort_clean.text:
You choose the linen by touch.

Clean to one side.

Stained to the other.

It feels sensible.

A guard glances at the piles and frowns—just once.

The numbers mattered more than the fabric.

r_linen_swap.text:
Two tags trade places.

The move is small.

The consequence is not.

You don’t know that yet.

A worker beside you exhales sharply through the nose—almost a laugh, almost a warning.

r_linen_memorize.text:
You read the wax marks as if they are scripture.

They repeat.

Not many.

A narrow range.

You notice gaps where a number should be.

The Gate does not label what it removes.

work_plaque_1.text:
You are given a damp cloth.

A wall of plaques waits in the dim.

Numbers etched into metal.

Not names.

The task is to wipe them clean.

The trick is that you can’t tell if the dust is age or evidence.

choices.label: Clean only the plaques you’re pointed to.
Clean extra plaques to be safe.
Run your thumb along an etched groove.

r_plaque_assigned.text:
You clean what you’re told to clean.

Your cloth turns gray.

A guard nods without meeting your eyes.

Procedure rewards procedure.

r_plaque_extra.text:
You move beyond your assigned section.

Not rebellion.

Overcompliance.

Your shoulders begin to ache.

A clerk watches you for a long moment, then looks away.

That feels worse than being stopped.

r_plaque_groove.text:
Your thumb finds the cut in the metal.

The groove is deeper than it should be.

A tiny burr catches your skin.

It pricks.

You taste iron in your mouth though there is no blood.

The plaque numbers feel less like labels and more like locks.

r_plaque_patterns.text:
You note repetition.

A number appears twice.

Another is missing entirely.

Your mind reaches for meaning.

The Gate gives you none.

A guard’s shadow crosses the plaques, slow and deliberate.

work_mortar_1.text:
You are given a dull scraper.

In a side corridor, old mortar has been disturbed—repaired, then repaired again.

The task is to smooth the seam.

It is work meant to erase work.

You kneel.

Stone presses cold through your knees.

choices.label: Scrape deeper, searching for the edge.
Work fast, as if speed is virtue.

r_mortar_shallow.text:
You skim the surface.

The seam remains, but it looks uniform.

That is the point.

A guard’s boots stop nearby.

He watches your hands until you steady your pace.

Then he moves on.

r_mortar_deep.text:
Your scraper bites.

The mortar gives way in a thin line.

Cold air touches your knuckles.

A breath from somewhere that is not this corridor.

Your heart jumps.

You cover the gap instinctively.

The Gate does not react.

Which is how you know it noticed.

r_mortar_listen.text:
You stop between strokes.

In the silence, you hear a second rhythm.

Not brushes.

Not footsteps.

Something like a distant chain settling.

You scrape again, slower.

r_mortar_fast.text:
You work quickly.

Mortar dust rises.

Your lungs tighten.

A cough threatens.

You swallow it down.

Speed is not virtue here.

It’s exposure.

work_crates_1.text:
Crates wait in a narrow bay.

Not heavy enough to be punishment.

Heavy enough to be consequence.

Each is stamped with the same seal:
no words.
just a circle and a line through it.

The task is relocation.

From one side of the bay to the other.

As if movement alone proves usefulness.

choices.label: Lift carefully. One crate at a time.
Drag a crate to save your back.
Ask another worker to lift with you.
Study the seal before moving anything.

r_crate_careful.text:
You lift with measured breath.

The crate shifts once, then settles.

A guard watches your form like a craftsman.

No correction.

No approval.

Just evaluation.

r_crate_drag.text:
Wood grinds against stone.

The sound travels.

Several heads turn.

A guard’s gaze lands on you and stays there.

You finish anyway.

Your arms shake afterward.

r_crate_help.text:
You meet someone’s eyes.

A silent question.

They step in.

You lift together.

For a moment it feels like coordination.

Then you realize you’ve made something visible.

A guard’s attention finds you both.

r_crate_seal.text:
The seal is simple.

A circle.

A line.

Not prohibition.

Erasure.

You don’t know what that means yet.

But you feel the meaning anyway.

You lift the crate.

It feels heavier after you looked.
